text: I never intended to become a political
activist you know as I just said it's
not my natural
um you know
field uh but here's what happened I grew
up in a a time and place that was about
the best
manifestation of the democratic process
that you could imagine I grew up in um
San Francisco in the 60s and 70s and the
hate ashberry in particular um and apart
from stereotypes about the hate ashbery
one thing that was definitely happening
in San Francisco as I was growing up is
that absolutely ordinary people were
organizing and making gigantic changes
and it was a fantastic feeling you know
there was a proposition put on the
ballot to get gay teachers out of the
school system and I watched the the fear
that that put into my own high school
teachers you know and then I saw the gay
and lesbian Community but also just
ordinary American citizens parents and
PT standing up and saying oh no you
don't you know and they pushed back and
they defeated it and I watched that I
watched those conversations where
parents were like wait a minute these
are really good teachers you know I
don't want my kid to lose this teacher
because of their private life that's
nobody's business you know I'm not going
to stand for that um the the Chinese
Community you know immigrants very many
of them very poor and many of them not
long in this country they didn't have
they weren't the entrenched Elite but
they had organized and they had a real
voice in City Hall and it was exciting
because it meant that there were
opportunities you know for immigrants in
the city that really there weren't uh on
the East Coast when I grew up and went
to college there um so I saw how
absolutely Ordinary People even poor
people could really show leadership and
have a voice and you know I saw the the
gay community organized and the women's
you know women's Liberation the women's
movement organized and you know the
civil rights movement that sort of tail
end of it and I just absolutely grew up
knowing that America was this beautiful
shining place where if something was
wrong you could fix it and you could
talk to your neighbors and you could um
talk to City Hall and you could stage a
protest and you could uh you know that
was Freedom it really was and I I really
saw wow this is why everyone wants to
live here this is so good
um so I guess having been imprinted with
that I I became a political activist by
default because when I to my shock you
know I sort of grew up and came East and
uh left this little bubble of peace and
Justice
and I found it so offensive and
upsetting that there are so many
barriers to people being able to do
what's right or have the society that
they want to have um and that people in
power control
so much in a way that you know isn't
intended to be the case in America in
terms of our voice and our access to the
Democratic process that I guess just as
a a function of my discomfort with that
I you know I feel committed to
addressing it and and changing it also
now that I'm a mom it really you know
lights a fire because it's bad for kids
in a in a close Society it's bad for
women and it's bad for children I don't
even want to tell you what happens to
women and children in a closed Society
um but as a feminist you know there is
no better place to grow up than a strong
constitutional republic and there is no
better place to be a woman than in a
strong constitutional republic so we
can't afford to lose those rights for
our
kids
